title: 105_hr3478
content:
The "Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998" provide for a final settlement of the claims of the Colorado Ute Indian Tribes by agreeing to reduced water supply facilities. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms used in the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988, such as "Agreement," "Animas-La Plata Project," "Dolores Project," and "Tribe; tribes." After the Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998, the Secretary will construct a reservoir with a storage capacity of 260,000 acre-feet as part of the Animas-La Plata Project. This project will also include a pumping plant and reservoir inlet conduit to provide municipal and industrial water allocations to the Southern Ute Tribe, not exceeding 16,525 acre-feet annually. The water allocations under the Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998 are as follows: 
- Southern Ute Tribe: 16,525 acre-feet annually
- Ute Mountain Ute Indian Tribe: 16,525 acre-feet annually
- Navajo Nation: 2,340 acre-feet annually
- San Juan Water Commission: 10,400 acre-feet annually
- Animas-La Plata Conservancy District: 2,600 acre-feet annually. The Animas-La Plata Project involves water allocations for different entities, with the Navajo Nation receiving 2,340 acre-feet annually. Tribal construction costs are nonreimbursable, while nontribal water capital repayment obligations will be covered by various entities, including the San Juan Water Commission, Animas-La Plata Water Conservancy District, and the State of Colorado. The State of Colorado's cost-sharing obligation for the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement and Animas-La Plata Project is up to $16,000,000. Certain nonreimbursable costs for recreation, environmental compliance, cultural resources protection, and fish and wildlife mitigation are specified. The Secretary will cover operation, maintenance, and replacement costs for tribal water allocations until used by the Tribe. The Secretary will pay for operation, maintenance, and replacement costs for tribal water allocations until used by the Tribe. Repayment of construction costs for the Dolores Project will commence when the water allocation is first used by the Tribe. The Tribe is not required to reimburse the Secretary for these costs. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to provide water allocations to specific districts with annual depletion limits. The Secretary will cover operation, maintenance, and replacement costs for tribal water allocations until used by the Tribe. Repayment of construction costs for the Dolores Project will start when the water allocation is utilized by the Tribe, with no reimbursement required. The Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988 is amended to allocate water to specific districts with annual depletion limits. The Secretary will cover operation, maintenance, and replacement costs for tribal water allocations until used by the Tribe. Repayment of construction costs for the Dolores Project will start when the water allocation is utilized by the Tribe, with no reimbursement required. Additionally, the Secretary shall transfer water rights to the New Mexico Animas-La Plata Project beneficiaries or the State of New Mexico upon request of the State Engineer, in accordance with applicable State law. The Secretary will transfer water rights to New Mexico Animas-La Plata Project beneficiaries or the State of New Mexico upon request of the State Engineer, in accordance with applicable State law. Reports related to the project will be considered adequate to meet requirements under the Endangered Species Act and the National Environmental Policy Act. The Animas-La Plata Project's compliance with the Endangered Species Act, National Environmental Policy Act, and Federal Water Pollution Control Act is ensured. Construction of specified facilities and water usage are covered, with no impact on other facilities or water uses. Final Settlement: Providing water to the Tribes as per the section will settle their water rights on the Animas and La Plata Rivers. The Tribes retain rights on other streams and rivers mentioned in the Agreement, can participate in the project, receive allocated water, and acquire water rights under Colorado laws. The Attorney General of the United States will file necessary instruments with the District Court, Water Division Number 7, of the State of Colorado to request amending the final consent decree for the Animas-La Plata Project and tribal water rights under the Colorado Ute Settlement Act Amendments of 1998. SEC. 4. STATUTORY CONSTRUCTION; TREATMENT OF CERTAIN FUNDS. The amendments made by this Act to section 6 of the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement of 1988 do not affect the applicability of other provisions of the Act or the Secretary of the Interior's obligation to deliver water from the Dolores Project and complete construction of facilities on the Ute Mountain Ute Indian Reservation as specified in various Appropriations Acts. The uncommitted portion of the cost-sharing obligation of the State of Colorado, as mentioned in the Colorado Ute Indian Water Rights Settlement Act of 1988, can be used to fund components of the Animas-La Plata Project not covered in the Act.
